bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Willard L. Beaulac, February 4, 1953

div1.p: Hench is sending Beaulac his memorandum on the dedication of Camp Lazear. He hopes the American Embassy will be called on to participate in other ceremonies at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Willard L. Beaulac, February 4, 1953
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
February 4, 1953
PHILIP S. HENCH, M. D.
CHARLES H. SLOCUMB, M. D.
HOWARD F. POLLEY, M. D.
EMMERSON WARD, M. D.
Mr. Willard L. Beaulac
U. S. Ambassador to Cuba
United States Embassy
Habana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Beaulac:
div1.p:
Thank you very kindly indeed for sending me the seating plan of the dinner.
Actually I did not request nor did I know that there was a formal blue print
of the seating arrangement and I am sorry that you went to some trouble to
get this. I was merely desirous of having an identification of the people
around the table which I thought you could give me off-hand. Nevertheless
I am glad to have the formal diagram. I showed it to my wife last night
and suggested that we make such a diagram from now on for every social af-
fair at Maison Hench. Her reply was unprintable!

Thank you also for the extra set of pictures, a couple of which were quite
“fullsome” if you know what I mean.

Permit me to enclose a memorandum on the dedication of Camp Lazear which
I sent in the form of a personal letter to the one survivor and to the rela-
tives of those most concerned. I am also enclosing a confidential memorandum
which went only to a selected few. The confidential addendum represents
only my personal opinions and views but I think it is essentially correct.

Mr. Beaulac, let me say again how very much I appreciated your help and I am sure
that even you may not realize how important it seemed to those of us con-
cerned with the dedication. Because of the Christmas holidays and other
activities which I interrupted for my rather hasty trip to Cuba, I was not
able to compose the enclosed memorandum of January 3 before that date. I
was most desirous of expressing my appreciation of your services to the
Secretary of State. This I did on January 12, sending it to Secretary
Acheson. As we mailed the letter about January 14 I realized that Mr.
Acheson's term was coming quickly to a close. I wondered in any event
whether he would ever see such a letter but I sent it on. May I ask you
personally whether it would serve my purpose (not yours) if I were to send
a similar letter to Secretary Dulles? I know he has just gone to Europe
but the Acting or Assistant Secretary might see it. Or would it be merely
passed down the line until it came to the same department that presumably
saw my letter of January 12? I am very sincere in wishing to let your
chiefs in Washington know about the generous activities of yourself and
your colleagues and indeed about the whole project.

Two or three of the officials connected with the dedication later said
“Now we have in Marianao the finest rallying point for an expression of
Mr. Willard L. Beaulac
- 2 -
February 4, 1953
Cuban American friendship and cooperation which will be rededicated each
year on December 3 with ceremonies.” If that is the case, your embassy
may well be called upon to participate in other ceremonies at Camp Lazear
and indeed I hope you will be, and your successors in Havana and your
chiefs in Washington should know something of the true significance of the
place.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
P.S.: As a polite guest I sent my brief thanks for the dinner party to
President Batista, a copy is enclosed.
I enclose a photograph of you unveiling Reed's medallion. You appear in
several other photographs in the list that I am sending to you, see Nos. 18
through 19. Some of these appeared in the paper. Should you wish copies
and if Doctor Nogueira did not send them to you, I have many of these films
and we can get them printed by a local photographer.
